elements.content: Calix[4]arene bearing phosphonic acid groups with different degrees of deprotonation in the para-positions bind Ca2+ in the solid state, forming complexes with a 2:5 or 1:1 calixarene:metal ion ratio for complexes 1 and 2, respectively. The cone-shaped calixarenes are organized into bilayers of similar packing ilk, with the nature of the calixarene interplay mapped out using Hirshfeld surface analysis. The cavities of the calixarenes are directed normal to the plane of the bilayers, with the bilayers bridged by metal ions bound to phosphonate O-centers, with additional coordination involving water molecules. Calixarenes from adjacent bilayers in complex 1 are aligned as “molecular capsules” with metal ions around their equatorial seam.
elements.clean_text: Calix[4]arene bearing phosphonic acid groups with different degrees of deprotonation in the para-positions bind Ca2+ in the solid state, forming complexes with a 2:5 or 1:1 calixarene:metal ion ratio for complexes 1 and 2, respectively. The cone-shaped calixarenes are organized into bilayers of similar packing ilk, with the nature of the calixarene interplay mapped out using Hirshfeld surface analysis. The cavities of the calixarenes are directed normal to the plane of the bilayers, with the bilayers bridged by metal ions bound to phosphonate O-centers, with additional coordination involving water molecules. Calixarenes from adjacent bilayers in complex 1 are aligned as "molecular capsules" with metal ions around their equatorial seam.

elements.content: para-Phosphonic acid calix[4]arene is shown to bind Ca2+ in the solid state, forming two different complexes that have been characterized by structural and Hirshfeld surface analysis. The complexes assemble into bilayers of similar packing ilk, although displaying different degrees of deprotonation of the phosphonate groups, and have calixarene:metal ion ratios of 2:5 and 1:1 for 1 and 2, respectively.
elements.clean_text: para-Phosphonic acid calix[4]arene is shown to bind Ca2+ in the solid state, forming two different complexes that have been characterized by structural and Hirshfeld surface analysis. The complexes assemble into bilayers of similar packing ilk, although displaying different degrees of deprotonation of the phosphonate groups, and have calixarene:metal ion ratios of 2:5 and 1:1 for 1 and 2, respectively.

elements.content: Calixarenes are macrocyclic compounds comprising phenolic units bridged by methylene groups through the 2,6-positions, with complexation capabilities for a wide variety of guests, including fullerenes and carboranes and metal ions, among many others. They are formed through the condensation reaction of p-substituted phenols and formaldehyde in the presence of acid or base under various conditions, those available in the highest yields being the tetramer, hexamer, and octamer, whereas the pentamer and heptamer, and higher-order calixarenes beyond calix[8]arene, are less well developed because of more challenging synthetic protocols. Calix[4]arene is by far the most widely studied and continues to deliver on a remarkable diversity of structures, depending on nature of the substituent para to the phenolic oxygen, and/or the nature of the group attached to these oxygen centers. Those devoid of such substitutents usually adopt the cone conformation, because of a circular network of hydrogen bonds associated with the so-called “lower-rim” phenolic OH groups.
elements.clean_text: Calixarenes are macrocyclic compounds comprising phenolic units bridged by methylene groups through the 2,6-positions, with complexation capabilities for a wide variety of guests, including fullerenes and carboranes and metal ions, among many others. They are formed through the condensation reaction of p-substituted phenols and formaldehyde in the presence of acid or base under various conditions, those available in the highest yields being the tetramer, hexamer, and octamer, whereas the pentamer and heptamer, and higher-order calixarenes beyond calix[8]arene, are less well developed because of more challenging synthetic protocols. Calix[4]arene is by far the most widely studied and continues to deliver on a remarkable diversity of structures, depending on nature of the substituent para to the phenolic oxygen, and/or the nature of the group attached to these oxygen centers. Those devoid of such substitutents usually adopt the cone conformation, because of a circular network of hydrogen bonds associated with the so-called "lower-rim" phenolic OH groups.

elements.content: Recently, we established a facile synthesis of water-soluble p-phosphonated calix[n]arene (n = 4, 5, 6, 8) involving a six-step procedure in overall 62% yield. The phosphonated calix[4]arene forms nanorafts upon dissolution in water, crystallizing in a bilayer arrangement, with water molecules either intercalated within the bilayer structure or forming a more compact structure devoid of interbilayer water molecules. This establishes the prowess of the calixarene in self-assembly processes, and the scene is set to develop the supramolecular chemistry of this functional cavitand. In contrast, the corresponding calix[4]arene bearing isoelectric sulfonic acid groups on the upper rim forms a plethora of self-assembled structures, including spectacular icosahedral and cuboctahedral arrays, as well as complex bilayer arrangements.
elements.clean_text: Recently, we established a facile synthesis of water-soluble p-phosphonated calix[n]arene (n = 4, 5, 6, 8) involving a six-step procedure in overall 62% yield. The phosphonated calix[4]arene forms nanorafts upon dissolution in water, crystallizing in a bilayer arrangement, with water molecules either intercalated within the bilayer structure or forming a more compact structure devoid of interbilayer water molecules. This establishes the prowess of the calixarene in self-assembly processes, and the scene is set to develop the supramolecular chemistry of this functional cavitand. In contrast, the corresponding calix[4]arene bearing isoelectric sulfonic acid groups on the upper rim forms a plethora of self-assembled structures, including spectacular icosahedral and cuboctahedral arrays, as well as complex bilayer arrangements.

elements.content: The limited self-assembly work for the phosphonated system relates to the lack of a robust high yielding system, which has now been addressed, and to the complexities of having an additional ionizable proton on each functional group. This affects the molecule in terms of the build up of additional charge, different metal complexation abilities, and the ability to form extended hydrogen-bonded arrays for all of the phosphonic acid calixarenes, as well as partially deprotonated analogues. This is highlighted in the present work, the understanding of which is facilitated using Hirshfeld surface analysis.
elements.clean_text: The limited self-assembly work for the phosphonated system relates to the lack of a robust high yielding system, which has now been addressed, and to the complexities of having an additional ionizable proton on each functional group. This affects the molecule in terms of the build up of additional charge, different metal complexation abilities, and the ability to form extended hydrogen-bonded arrays for all of the phosphonic acid calixarenes, as well as partially deprotonated analogues. This is highlighted in the present work, the understanding of which is facilitated using Hirshfeld surface analysis.

elements.content: Hirshfeld surface analysis is a recently developed tool for mapping the properties of the surfaces of molecules in the solid state, including their shape index, curvedness and normalized contact distances among other parameters. The parameter d norm is of particular interest, as it displays a surface where contacts shorter than the sum of their van der Waals radii have negative values and uses a red−white−blue color scheme. Hirshfeld surfaces have proved very useful in the visualization of the crystal structures of both small and large molecules, with the surfaces themselves and fingerprint plots able to discern differences that one may not be able to realize just through visual inspection of the crystal structure.
elements.clean_text: Hirshfeld surface analysis is a recently developed tool for mapping the properties of the surfaces of molecules in the solid state, including their shape index, curvedness and normalized contact distances among other parameters. The parameter d norm is of particular interest, as it displays a surface where contacts shorter than the sum of their van der Waals radii have negative values and uses a red-white-blue color scheme. Hirshfeld surfaces have proved very useful in the visualization of the crystal structures of both small and large molecules, with the surfaces themselves and fingerprint plots able to discern differences that one may not be able to realize just through visual inspection of the crystal structure.

elements.content: In developing the self-assembly of the phosphonated Calix[4]arene toward metal ions we have investigated the complexation of calcium ions in aqueous media, and have established the formation of two discrete complexes, depending on the reaction conditions, Scheme . Both complexes crystallize as bilayers, with the complex displaying higher calcium loading taking on the equivalent of a self-assembled molecular capsules. They have been studied using Hirshfeld surface analysis in understanding subtle differences of the calixarene environment in the bilayer structures with increasing uptake of metal ions, i.e., greater deprotonation of the phosphonic acid groups. It is noteworthy that the complexation of calcium by the poly phosphonate in water has implications in the binding of calcium in biological processes, including their role in tumor growth, specifically in breast cancer cells, as well as the role that calcium uptake plays in Alzheimer’s disease.
elements.clean_text: In developing the self-assembly of the phosphonated Calix[4]arene toward metal ions we have investigated the complexation of calcium ions in aqueous media, and have established the formation of two discrete complexes, depending on the reaction conditions, Scheme . Both complexes crystallize as bilayers, with the complex displaying higher calcium loading taking on the equivalent of a self-assembled molecular capsules. They have been studied using Hirshfeld surface analysis in understanding subtle differences of the calixarene environment in the bilayer structures with increasing uptake of metal ions, i.e., greater deprotonation of the phosphonic acid groups. It is noteworthy that the complexation of calcium by the poly phosphonate in water has implications in the binding of calcium in biological processes, including their role in tumor growth, specifically in breast cancer cells, as well as the role that calcium uptake plays in Alzheimer's disease.

elements.content:
Conditions Used in the Crystallizations of Complexes <bold>1</bold> and <bold>2</bold> <xref rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

It can be seen that two distinct complexes form, depending on the addition of an organic molecule, such as choline chloride, to the reaction mixture.
elements.clean_text: 1  Conditions Used in the Crystallizations of Complexes 1 and 2       a It can be seen that two distinct complexes form, depending on the addition of an organic molecule, such as choline chloride, to the reaction mixture.

elements.content:
It can be seen that two distinct complexes form, depending on the addition of an organic molecule, such as choline chloride, to the reaction mixture.

Results and Discussion

Reaction of the p-phosphonic acid calix[4]arene dissolved in water by adding a small amount of aqueous NH3 with calcium acetate added in different ratios, followed by concentration by slow evaporation, reproducibly gave complex 1 (Scheme ) with a 2:5 ratio of calixarene relative to calcium ions. The addition of choline chloride and methanol to the same reaction mixture, and a similar concentration by slow evaporation, reproducibly gave complex 2 with a 1:1 ratio of calixarene relative to calcium.
elements.clean_text:
a It can be seen that two distinct complexes form, depending on the addition of an organic molecule, such as choline chloride, to the reaction mixture.  

Results and Discussion

Reaction of the p-phosphonic acid calix[4]arene dissolved in water by adding a small amount of aqueous NH3 with calcium acetate added in different ratios, followed by concentration by slow evaporation, reproducibly gave complex 1 (Scheme ) with a 2:5 ratio of calixarene relative to calcium ions. The addition of choline chloride and methanol to the same reaction mixture, and a similar concentration by slow evaporation, reproducibly gave complex 2 with a 1:1 ratio of calixarene relative to calcium.

elements.content: The best results for the formation of 1 in terms of single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction studies were for calixarene to calcium ratio in the range 1:2 to 1:3. A ratio smaller than ca. 1:1.5 gave small needlelike crystals that were not suitable for X-ray analysis. Here, the addition of calcium acetate to the reaction mixture gave an immediate precipitate (presumably Ca(OH)2) because of the excess of Ca ions in a basic solution. Ratios larger than the optimal range showed either some crystallization of complex 1, albeit unsuitable for X-ray studies, or no crystalline material, although in all cases a brown precipitate of unknown composition was evident.
elements.clean_text: The best results for the formation of 1 in terms of single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction studies were for calixarene to calcium ratio in the range 1:2 to 1:3. A ratio smaller than ca. 1:1.5 gave small needlelike crystals that were not suitable for X-ray analysis. Here, the addition of calcium acetate to the reaction mixture gave an immediate precipitate (presumably Ca(OH)2) because of the excess of Ca ions in a basic solution. Ratios larger than the optimal range showed either some crystallization of complex 1, albeit unsuitable for X-ray studies, or no crystalline material, although in all cases a brown precipitate of unknown composition was evident.

elements.content: There are two other crystal structures for this compound, as discussed above, where metal ions are necessary to effect crystallization of the tetra-phosphonic acid, and the formation of complex 1 is the first instance where the metal ions present during crystallization are incorporated into the crystal structure, with some deprotonation of the phosphonic acid groups. Moreover, unlike the other reported structures, the presence of organic molecules is not required to afford crystallization of the calixarene.
elements.clean_text: There are two other crystal structures for this compound, as discussed above, where metal ions are necessary to effect crystallization of the tetra-phosphonic acid, and the formation of complex 1 is the first instance where the metal ions present during crystallization are incorporated into the crystal structure, with some deprotonation of the phosphonic acid groups. Moreover, unlike the other reported structures, the presence of organic molecules is not required to afford crystallization of the calixarene.

elements.content: Complex 1 has the formula moiety 2(C28H23O16P4), Ca5, 22(H2O), crystallizing in the monoclinic space group P21 /n (Z = 2), with the asymmetric unit containing one calix[4]arene in the cone conformation bound to calcium atoms, Figure . Because of symmetry conditions, one of the calcium atoms is half-populated, indicating its presence/absence in different asymmetric units, whereas the remaining two calcium atoms take fully occupied positions. This situation also affects the interpretation of “disorder” of some crystalline water molecules, with the water molecules occupying slightly different positions in the crystal in the absence of a calcium atom.
elements.clean_text: Complex 1 has the formula moiety 2(C28H23O16P4), Ca5, 22(H2O), crystallizing in the monoclinic space group P21 /n (Z = 2), with the asymmetric unit containing one calix[4]arene in the cone conformation bound to calcium atoms, Figure . Because of symmetry conditions, one of the calcium atoms is half-populated, indicating its presence/absence in different asymmetric units, whereas the remaining two calcium atoms take fully occupied positions. This situation also affects the interpretation of "disorder" of some crystalline water molecules, with the water molecules occupying slightly different positions in the crystal in the absence of a calcium atom.

elements.content: (a, b) Comparison of complex 1 to complex 2. Water molecules and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity, as well as the methanol molecule bound in the calixarene cavity in complex 2. Disordered calcium atoms in 1 have been modeled as fully occupied.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a, b) Comparison of complex 1 to complex 2. Water molecules and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity, as well as the methanol molecule bound in the calixarene cavity in complex 2. Disordered calcium atoms in 1 have been modeled as fully occupied.

elements.content: Of the three calcium atoms present in the asymmetric unit, one of them (Ca1) displays octahedral coordination, whereas the other two calcium atoms are seven-coordinated, in the manner of an augmented triangular prism, Figure . Ca1 and Ca2 are bridged by two oxygen atoms (O···P, shown in Figure as blue), whereas Ca3 is bound to a water molecule that lies in close proximity to an inversion center. Red oxygens are from water molecules, and two of the oxygens attached to Ca2 are disordered because of the presence or absence of Ca2 in the complex. Remarkably, one water molecule is located almost at the center of the calixarene cavity, displaying OH···π bonding to two opposite aromatic rings with O···π distances 3.25 and 3.24 Å, in a manner similar to that of a sulfonated calix[5]arene crystal structure that has previously been published in the literature. The calixarene has a −5 overall charge, thus losing 5 out of a possible 8 hydrogen atoms from the phosphonic acid group located at the upper rim. The lower rim of the calixarene remains protonated, and a strong circular hydrogen bonded network ensues, consistent with the calixarene in the cone conformation. The oxygen-bonded hydrogen atoms are involved in a H-bond network with O···O distances in the range of 2.484(4)−3.481(13) Å.
elements.clean_text: Of the three calcium atoms present in the asymmetric unit, one of them (Ca1) displays octahedral coordination, whereas the other two calcium atoms are seven-coordinated, in the manner of an augmented triangular prism, Figure . Ca1 and Ca2 are bridged by two oxygen atoms (O⋅⋅⋅P, shown in Figure  as blue), whereas Ca3 is bound to a water molecule that lies in close proximity to an inversion center. Red oxygens are from water molecules, and two of the oxygens attached to Ca2 are disordered because of the presence or absence of Ca2 in the complex. Remarkably, one water molecule is located almost at the center of the calixarene cavity, displaying OH⋅⋅⋅π bonding to two opposite aromatic rings with O⋅⋅⋅π distances 3.25 and 3.24 Å, in a manner similar to that of a sulfonated calix[5]arene crystal structure that has previously been published in the literature. The calixarene has a -5 overall charge, thus losing 5 out of a possible 8 hydrogen atoms from the phosphonic acid group located at the upper rim. The lower rim of the calixarene remains protonated, and a strong circular hydrogen bonded network ensues, consistent with the calixarene in the cone conformation. The oxygen-bonded hydrogen atoms are involved in a H-bond network with O⋅⋅⋅O distances in the range of 2.484(4)-3.481(13) Å.

elements.content: Diagram displaying the bridging and coordination of calcium atoms in complex 1, where two calcium atoms (Ca2 and Ca3) are seven-coordinated and one calcium atom (Ca1) is octahedrally coordinated. Blue-colored atoms denote oxygens that represent O-centers in the phosphonate headgroup of the calixarene. The disorder present in Ca2 is evident in the pairs of oxygen atoms in close proximity.
elements.clean_text: 2  Diagram displaying the bridging and coordination of calcium atoms in complex 1, where two calcium atoms (Ca2 and Ca3) are seven-coordinated and one calcium atom (Ca1) is octahedrally coordinated. Blue-colored atoms denote oxygens that represent O-centers in the phosphonate headgroup of the calixarene. The disorder present in Ca2 is evident in the pairs of oxygen atoms in close proximity.

elements.content: Complex 2 has the formula (C28H26O16P4), Ca, 3(H2O), CH4O and crystallizes in the tetragonal space group P4/ncc, with the asymmetric unit containing one phenolic ring, one phosphonic acid group at the upper rim attached to a calcium atom, as well as a methanol and water molecule at special positions, Figure . A methanol molecule is present whose CH3 group points toward the cavity of the calixarene molecule. One of the water molecules is involved in the coordination sphere of the Ca atom, whereas the second one is a solvent molecule and highly disordered. In the complex, the phosphonic acid groups possessing a single bond are disordered, and only one hydrogen atom is present for each phosphonic acid group. These hydrogen atoms are spread over two possible positions associated with the disorder present in the structure. The total charge of the calixarene is −2, which corresponds to two of the phosphonate groups having a delocalized proton. The coordination sphere of the Ca atom is a distorted octahedron, which involves one crystalline water molecule and oxygen atoms of a disordered phosphonic acid group and their symmetry equivalents, with Ca···O distances 2.32(2)−2.37(2) Å.
elements.clean_text: Complex 2 has the formula (C28H26O16P4), Ca, 3(H2O), CH4O and crystallizes in the tetragonal space group P4/ncc, with the asymmetric unit containing one phenolic ring, one phosphonic acid group at the upper rim attached to a calcium atom, as well as a methanol and water molecule at special positions, Figure . A methanol molecule is present whose CH3 group points toward the cavity of the calixarene molecule. One of the water molecules is involved in the coordination sphere of the Ca atom, whereas the second one is a solvent molecule and highly disordered. In the complex, the phosphonic acid groups possessing a single bond are disordered, and only one hydrogen atom is present for each phosphonic acid group. These hydrogen atoms are spread over two possible positions associated with the disorder present in the structure. The total charge of the calixarene is -2, which corresponds to two of the phosphonate groups having a delocalized proton. The coordination sphere of the Ca atom is a distorted octahedron, which involves one crystalline water molecule and oxygen atoms of a disordered phosphonic acid group and their symmetry equivalents, with Ca⋅⋅⋅O distances 2.32(2)-2.37(2) Å.

elements.content: Complex 1 has a bilayer type arrangement, with the calixarene units packing in the traditional back to back type style, Figure , with the calixarene molecules being offset from one another along the c-axis, which is found in the structures of the parent calixarene. The phenolic hydroxyls may be involved in hydrogen bonds with the neighboring phenolic oxygens (2.661(4)−3.087(4) Å), and the calcium ions form an interstitial layer between the calixarenes, with the average spacing between neighboring calcium atoms being 3.96 Å.
elements.clean_text: Complex 1 has a bilayer type arrangement, with the calixarene units packing in the traditional back to back type style, Figure , with the calixarene molecules being offset from one another along the c-axis, which is found in the structures of the parent calixarene. The phenolic hydroxyls may be involved in hydrogen bonds with the neighboring phenolic oxygens (2.661(4)-3.087(4) Å), and the calcium ions form an interstitial layer between the calixarenes, with the average spacing between neighboring calcium atoms being 3.96 Å.

elements.content: Packing diagrams of complex (a) 1 and (b) 2. Complex 1 is viewed down the c axis, and complex 2 is viewed down the b axis. The calixarene molecules are represented by spacefilling diagrams, whereas the calcium atoms and coordinated waters have been left as ball and stick representation, with hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity. Noteworthy are the extra waters coordinated to the calciums of 1 and the closer packing of the calixarenes in 2.
elements.clean_text: 3  Packing diagrams of complex (a) 1 and (b) 2. Complex 1 is viewed down the c axis, and complex 2 is viewed down the b axis. The calixarene molecules are represented by spacefilling diagrams, whereas the calcium atoms and coordinated waters have been left as ball and stick representation, with hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity. Noteworthy are the extra waters coordinated to the calciums of 1 and the closer packing of the calixarenes in 2.

elements.content: In complex 2, the lower rim of the calixarene remains protonated, thus preserving the cone conformation. As projected down the b-axis of the crystal, the phosphonic acid group of one calixarene unit is oriented toward the cavity of an opposite calixarene, as is commonly observed for calixarenes in general, and a comparison between the structures is shown in Figure . The calixarene molecules form a bilayer structure perpendicular to the c axis with Ca atoms that are connected to phosphonic acid groups forming a polymeric square network with a Ca···Ca distance of 8.24 Å. The complex of 2 differs from 1 in both the number of water molecules present in the structure and the size of the bilayer, with the Ca···Ca distance along the bilayer (c) axis being 13.72 Å in 2, whereas in 1 (where the bilayer axis corresponds to the b axis) the bilayer size is 12.85 Å, hence showing that 1 is the more compact structure.
elements.clean_text: In complex 2, the lower rim of the calixarene remains protonated, thus preserving the cone conformation. As projected down the b-axis of the crystal, the phosphonic acid group of one calixarene unit is oriented toward the cavity of an opposite calixarene, as is commonly observed for calixarenes in general, and a comparison between the structures is shown in Figure . The calixarene molecules form a bilayer structure perpendicular to the c axis with Ca atoms that are connected to phosphonic acid groups forming a polymeric square network with a Ca⋅⋅⋅Ca distance of 8.24 Å. The complex of 2 differs from 1 in both the number of water molecules present in the structure and the size of the bilayer, with the Ca⋅⋅⋅Ca distance along the bilayer (c) axis being 13.72 Å in 2, whereas in 1 (where the bilayer axis corresponds to the b axis) the bilayer size is 12.85 Å, hence showing that 1 is the more compact structure.

elements.content: Hirshfeld surface analysis of the two structures differentiates some subtle differences that are not immediately visible. Figure displays the fingerprint plots for the calixarenes in complexes 1 and 2. Complex 1 displays three “spikes” that are immediately evident in the plot. The outermost spikes represent O···H hydrogen bonding interactions, highlighted in red, with the lower spike being the acceptor spike (involving oxygens from the calixarene and hydrogens from water molecules), and the upper spike being the donor spike (in which the roles are reversed, hydrogens from a protonated phosphonate group interacting with an oxygen atom). The acceptor spike is more intense than the donor spike, making up 27% of the Hirshfeld surface (compared to 9% for the donor spike), and this can be understood by the −5 charge on the calixarene, meaning that only 3 oxygens are protonated, as opposed to 5 deprotonated oxygens. The third spike, highlighted in green, which bisects the acceptor and donor spikes, results from close H··H contacts, principally one of the meta-hydrogens in the calixarene unit in close proximity to a water molecule bound outside of the calixarene.
elements.clean_text: Hirshfeld surface analysis of the two structures differentiates some subtle differences that are not immediately visible. Figure  displays the fingerprint plots for the calixarenes in complexes 1 and 2. Complex 1 displays three "spikes" that are immediately evident in the plot. The outermost spikes represent O⋅⋅⋅H hydrogen bonding interactions, highlighted in red, with the lower spike being the acceptor spike (involving oxygens from the calixarene and hydrogens from water molecules), and the upper spike being the donor spike (in which the roles are reversed, hydrogens from a protonated phosphonate group interacting with an oxygen atom). The acceptor spike is more intense than the donor spike, making up 27% of the Hirshfeld surface (compared to 9% for the donor spike), and this can be understood by the -5 charge on the calixarene, meaning that only 3 oxygens are protonated, as opposed to 5 deprotonated oxygens. The third spike, highlighted in green, which bisects the acceptor and donor spikes, results from close H⋅⋅H contacts, principally one of the meta-hydrogens in the calixarene unit in close proximity to a water molecule bound outside of the calixarene.

elements.content: Hirshfeld surface fingerprint plots for the calixarene moieties in complex 1 (left) and complex 2 (right) showing the distinct differences in the coordination of both calixarenes. In calculating these plots, we modeled disordered water (structure 1) and phosphonate groups (structure 2) as fully occupied over one position, instead of disordered over two positions. Structures 3 and 4 represent the parent p-phosphonic acid calix[4]arene, whose crystal structures incorporating methanol and water, respectively, in the calixarene cavity have been published in a previous paper.
elements.clean_text: 4  Hirshfeld surface fingerprint plots for the calixarene moieties in complex 1 (left) and complex 2 (right) showing the distinct differences in the coordination of both calixarenes. In calculating these plots, we modeled disordered water (structure 1) and phosphonate groups (structure 2) as fully occupied over one position, instead of disordered over two positions. Structures 3 and 4 represent the parent p-phosphonic acid calix[4]arene, whose crystal structures incorporating methanol and water, respectively, in the calixarene cavity have been published in a previous paper.

elements.content: The bottom right of the plot for complex 1 has a green spike (circled in yellow), resulting from the OH···π interaction between the ordered water molecule in the cavity of the calixarene and the phenol rings of the calixarene, with the OH···π distance approximately 2.6 Å. One more feature evident in the fingerprint plot for complex 1 is the Ca···O contacts, visible as a narrow yellow and red band, toward the upper left part of the plot. This particular interaction comprises 8% of the Hirshfeld surface and reflects the calcium atoms bound to deprotonated oxygen atoms of the calixarene.
elements.clean_text: The bottom right of the plot for complex 1 has a green spike (circled in yellow), resulting from the OH⋅⋅⋅π interaction between the ordered water molecule in the cavity of the calixarene and the phenol rings of the calixarene, with the OH⋅⋅⋅π distance approximately 2.6 Å. One more feature evident in the fingerprint plot for complex 1 is the Ca⋅⋅⋅O contacts, visible as a narrow yellow and red band, toward the upper left part of the plot. This particular interaction comprises 8% of the Hirshfeld surface and reflects the calcium atoms bound to deprotonated oxygen atoms of the calixarene.

elements.content: The fingerprint plot for complex 2 displays a number of different features from that of complex 1. First the O···H contacts (highlighted in red) are not as close as in complex 1. The O···H acceptor spike is again the lower spike and makes up only slightly more of the Hirshfeld surface than the acceptor spike. This is understandable, as the charge on the phosphonated calixarene in this structure is −2, meaning there are also 4 protonated phosphonate groups. Interestingly, one of the oxygens from the phosphonate group resides quite closely to the meta-hydrogen of a neighboring calixarene, indicating a strong interaction between layers, not just within them. The large spike in the plot (indicated by a green circle) is due to a very close contact between a water molecule that lies on a 2-fold symmetry axis and a hydrogen atom from the methylene bridge of the calixarene.
elements.clean_text: The fingerprint plot for complex 2 displays a number of different features from that of complex 1. First the O⋅⋅⋅H contacts (highlighted in red) are not as close as in complex 1. The O⋅⋅⋅H acceptor spike is again the lower spike and makes up only slightly more of the Hirshfeld surface than the acceptor spike. This is understandable, as the charge on the phosphonated calixarene in this structure is -2, meaning there are also 4 protonated phosphonate groups. Interestingly, one of the oxygens from the phosphonate group resides quite closely to the meta-hydrogen of a neighboring calixarene, indicating a strong interaction between layers, not just within them. The large spike in the plot (indicated by a green circle) is due to a very close contact between a water molecule that lies on a 2-fold symmetry axis and a hydrogen atom from the methylene bridge of the calixarene.

elements.content: In this fingerprint plot, we can also see feature characteristic of CH···π interactions, namely the “wings” on the plot, in the lower left and upper right of the plot (circled in orange). This interaction involves the methanol molecule inside the cavity, which sits on a 4-fold symmetry axis with its hydrogens pointing toward the phenyl rings of the calixarene. Also interesting is the band that extends from the CH···π acceptor region all the way toward the top of the plot. This band results from CH···π contacts involving the methylene hydrogen (which is pointing toward the lower phenolic ring of the calixarene) of one calixarene and the phenyl ring of a neighboring calixarene. The Ca···O region of the plot for complex 2 looks quite similar to that of 1; however, the difference lies in the amount of the surface that this interaction comprises. In complex 2, the Ca···O interaction comprises 5% of the surface, which is in part due to the higher loading of calcium in complex 1. Finally, one thing that is immediately obvious about the plot of complex 2 is that there are many long contacts compared with structure 1. This is because even though the bilayer in complex 2 is larger than complex 1, it is less dense and has fewer water molecules included into the structure; thus there is a lot of space above the phosphonate groups and the contacts between atoms are longer.
elements.clean_text: In this fingerprint plot, we can also see feature characteristic of CH⋅⋅⋅π interactions, namely the "wings" on the plot, in the lower left and upper right of the plot (circled in orange). This interaction involves the methanol molecule inside the cavity, which sits on a 4-fold symmetry axis with its hydrogens pointing toward the phenyl rings of the calixarene. Also interesting is the band that extends from the CH⋅⋅⋅π acceptor region all the way toward the top of the plot. This band results from CH⋅⋅⋅π contacts involving the methylene hydrogen (which is pointing toward the lower phenolic ring of the calixarene) of one calixarene and the phenyl ring of a neighboring calixarene. The Ca⋅⋅⋅O region of the plot for complex 2 looks quite similar to that of 1; however, the difference lies in the amount of the surface that this interaction comprises. In complex 2, the Ca⋅⋅⋅O interaction comprises 5% of the surface, which is in part due to the higher loading of calcium in complex 1. Finally, one thing that is immediately obvious about the plot of complex 2 is that there are many long contacts compared with structure 1. This is because even though the bilayer in complex 2 is larger than complex 1, it is less dense and has fewer water molecules included into the structure; thus there is a lot of space above the phosphonate groups and the contacts between atoms are longer.

elements.content: In comparison with the two other published crystal structures of phosphonated calix[4]arenes, both fingerprint plots are similar in shape, because of their similar chemical nature, with the only difference between the structures being a methanol molecule in the cavity of structure 3 as opposed to a disordered water molecule in the cavity of 4. In the fingerprint plot of structure 3, there are two spikes present because of O···H contacts, with the lower spike involving an oxygen from the protonated phosphonate ligand interacting with the oxygen from the disordered methanol molecule in the cavity. The other O···H interaction comes from the oxygens at the lower rim of the calixarene contacting the methylene hydrogens from the calixarene below. The methylene hydrogens also play a role in the CH···π bonding (characteristic of all fingerprint plots except structure 1) by interacting with the phenyl rings of neighboring calixarenes, as well as the methylene hydrogens of neighboring calixarenes. In this structure, the phosphonate ligands are disordered over two positions and have been modeled as fully occupied over only one position.
elements.clean_text: In comparison with the two other published crystal structures of phosphonated calix[4]arenes, both fingerprint plots are similar in shape, because of their similar chemical nature, with the only difference between the structures being a methanol molecule in the cavity of structure 3 as opposed to a disordered water molecule in the cavity of 4. In the fingerprint plot of structure 3, there are two spikes present because of O⋅⋅⋅H contacts, with the lower spike involving an oxygen from the protonated phosphonate ligand interacting with the oxygen from the disordered methanol molecule in the cavity. The other O⋅⋅⋅H interaction comes from the oxygens at the lower rim of the calixarene contacting the methylene hydrogens from the calixarene below. The methylene hydrogens also play a role in the CH⋅⋅⋅π bonding (characteristic of all fingerprint plots except structure 1) by interacting with the phenyl rings of neighboring calixarenes, as well as the methylene hydrogens of neighboring calixarenes. In this structure, the phosphonate ligands are disordered over two positions and have been modeled as fully occupied over only one position.

elements.content: Structure 4 is interesting in that there are two donor spikes in the fingerprint plot, as opposed to one for all of the other complexes. This is due to the phosphonate group of the calixarene being fully protonated, and having a different environment around each of the phosphonate arms. The donor spikes are due to the hydrogens from the protonated phosphonate ligands interacting with water molecules present in the structure and to the meta-hydrogens from the calixarene in close proximity to the phosphonate ligand of a neighboring calixarene. The usual CH···π interaction that is evident in previous structures is also present in this complex, with some H···H interactions due to the methylene hydrogens interacting with neighboring protons (as seen in structure 3) also present.
elements.clean_text: Structure 4 is interesting in that there are two donor spikes in the fingerprint plot, as opposed to one for all of the other complexes. This is due to the phosphonate group of the calixarene being fully protonated, and having a different environment around each of the phosphonate arms. The donor spikes are due to the hydrogens from the protonated phosphonate ligands interacting with water molecules present in the structure and to the meta-hydrogens from the calixarene in close proximity to the phosphonate ligand of a neighboring calixarene. The usual CH⋅⋅⋅π interaction that is evident in previous structures is also present in this complex, with some H⋅⋅⋅H interactions due to the methylene hydrogens interacting with neighboring protons (as seen in structure 3) also present.

elements.content: d norm surface representation of complex (a) 1 and (b) 2, mapped over the same color range. Less protonated 1 displays an O···H or O···Ca bond length shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of the two atoms, and this is displayed as red on the surface. Complex 2, with a net positive charge lower than that of 1, is characterized by fewer red spots on the d norm surface, thus indicating that the contacts in this molecule are closer to the sum of the van der Waals radii of the atoms.
elements.clean_text: 5   d norm surface representation of complex (a) 1 and (b) 2, mapped over the same color range. Less protonated 1 displays an O⋅⋅⋅H or O⋅⋅⋅Ca bond length shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of the two atoms, and this is displayed as red on the surface. Complex 2, with a net positive charge lower than that of 1, is characterized by fewer red spots on the d norm surface, thus indicating that the contacts in this molecule are closer to the sum of the van der Waals radii of the atoms.

elements.content: We have elucidated the structures of two complexes of the recently synthesized p-phosphonic acid calix[4]arene, with the crystal structures being the first to establish its binding prowess toward metal ions in the solid state. This has implications through the binding of calcium in applications such as cancer research, as certain types of cancers are known to increase the amount of calcium present in the body, as well as Alzheimer’s disease, where calcium uptake is known to play a role. We have also used Hirshfeld surfaces to investigate the structural differences of the two complexes, through inspection of both the mapped Hirshfeld surfaces themselves and also the fingerprint plots. This work can be extended into the investigation of binding studies of these calixarenes with further metals to obtain a more complete picture of the complementarity of metal ions with the calixarene macrocycle.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have elucidated the structures of two complexes of the recently synthesized p-phosphonic acid calix[4]arene, with the crystal structures being the first to establish its binding prowess toward metal ions in the solid state. This has implications through the binding of calcium in applications such as cancer research, as certain types of cancers are known to increase the amount of calcium present in the body, as well as Alzheimer's disease, where calcium uptake is known to play a role. We have also used Hirshfeld surfaces to investigate the structural differences of the two complexes, through inspection of both the mapped Hirshfeld surfaces themselves and also the fingerprint plots. This work can be extended into the investigation of binding studies of these calixarenes with further metals to obtain a more complete picture of the complementarity of metal ions with the calixarene macrocycle.

elements.content: p-Phosphonic acid calix[4]arene was prepared according to a known literature procedure. All starting materials and solvents were supplied commercially and used as supplied. Milli-Q water used was purified and had a resistance of 18MΩ. Compound 1 was prepared by the slow evaporation of 5 mL of a stock solution of 0.8 g/L solution of p-phosphonic acid (with 8 mL/L concentrated ammonia solution added) in water and 0.33−0.5 mol equiv. of calcium acetate. Single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction studies formed over the course of 3 days. The total yield of compound 1 obtained was 38%, and the powder X-ray diffraction calculated for the single crystal matched the measured powder X-ray diffraction pattern for the sample. Compound 2 was prepared by slow evaporation of the same stock solution; however, in this instance, a 0.5 mol ratio of calcium acetate was used, along with 5 mg of choline chloride. Single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction studies also formed over the course of 3 days. Insufficient material for powder diffraction studies was obtained, with the single-crystal structure determination showing the ability to form a compound containing the same components as in 1, but with a different ratio.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 p-Phosphonic acid calix[4]arene was prepared according to a known literature procedure. All starting materials and solvents were supplied commercially and used as supplied. Milli-Q water used was purified and had a resistance of 18MΩ. Compound 1 was prepared by the slow evaporation of 5 mL of a stock solution of 0.8 g/L solution of p-phosphonic acid (with 8 mL/L concentrated ammonia solution added) in water and 0.33-0.5 mol equiv. of calcium acetate. Single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction studies formed over the course of 3 days. The total yield of compound 1 obtained was 38%, and the powder X-ray diffraction calculated for the single crystal matched the measured powder X-ray diffraction pattern for the sample. Compound 2 was prepared by slow evaporation of the same stock solution; however, in this instance, a 0.5 mol ratio of calcium acetate was used, along with 5 mg of choline chloride. Single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction studies also formed over the course of 3 days. Insufficient material for powder diffraction studies was obtained, with the single-crystal structure determination showing the ability to form a compound containing the same components as in 1, but with a different ratio.

elements.content: The X-ray intensities were measured from single crystals of the title compounds on an Oxford Xcalibur-S Sapphire CCD diffractometer at 100K using monochromatic Mo Kα radiation. Data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and absorption correction applied using multiple symmetry equivalent reflections. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 using the SHELX-97 crystallographic package and X-seed interface. A full matrix least-squares refinement procedure was used, minimizing w(F o 2 − F c 2), with w = [σ2(F o 2) + (AP)2 + BP]−1, where P = (F o 2 + 2F c 2)/3. Agreement factors (R = Σ∥F o| − |F c∥/Σ|F o|, wR 2 = (Σ[w(F o 2 − F c 2)2]/Σ[w(F o 2)2])1/2 and GOF = (Σ[w(F o 2 − F c 2)2]/(n − p))1/2. Non-hydrogen nondisordered atoms were refined anisotropically. The positions of hydrogen atoms were partly localized from difference Fourier map, partly calculated from geometrical consideration, and their atomic parameters were constrained to the bonded atoms during the refinement. Hirshfeld surface analysis was undertaken with Crystal Explorer 2.1. The CCDC deposition numbers are 728985 and 728926.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The X-ray intensities were measured from single crystals of the title compounds on an Oxford Xcalibur-S Sapphire CCD diffractometer at 100K using monochromatic Mo Kα radiation. Data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and absorption correction applied using multiple symmetry equivalent reflections. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 using the SHELX-97 crystallographic package and X-seed interface. A full matrix least-squares refinement procedure was used, minimizing w(F o 2 - F c 2), with w = [σ2(F o 2) + (AP)2 + BP]-1, where P = (F o 2 + 2F c 2)/3. Agreement factors (R = Σ∥F o| - |F c∥/Σ|F o|, wR 2 = (Σ[w(F o 2 - F c 2)2]/Σ[w(F o 2)2])1/2 and GOF = (Σ[w(F o 2 - F c 2)2]/(n - p))1/2. Non-hydrogen nondisordered atoms were refined anisotropically. The positions of hydrogen atoms were partly localized from difference Fourier map, partly calculated from geometrical consideration, and their atomic parameters were constrained to the bonded atoms during the refinement. Hirshfeld surface analysis was undertaken with Crystal Explorer 2.1. The CCDC deposition numbers are 728985 and 728926.

cln_elements.content:
Conditions Used in the Crystallizations of Complexes <bold>1</bold> and <bold>2</bold> <xref rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

It can be seen that two distinct complexes form, depending on the addition of an organic molecule, such as choline chloride, to the reaction mixture.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Conditions Used in the Crystallizations of Complexes 1 and 2       a It can be seen that two distinct complexes form, depending on the addition of an organic molecule, such as choline chloride, to the reaction mixture.

cln_elements.content: (a, b) Comparison of complex 1 to complex 2. Water molecules and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity, as well as the methanol molecule bound in the calixarene cavity in complex 2. Disordered calcium atoms in 1 have been modeled as fully occupied.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a, b) Comparison of complex 1 to complex 2. Water molecules and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity, as well as the methanol molecule bound in the calixarene cavity in complex 2. Disordered calcium atoms in 1 have been modeled as fully occupied.

cln_elements.content: Diagram displaying the bridging and coordination of calcium atoms in complex 1, where two calcium atoms (Ca2 and Ca3) are seven-coordinated and one calcium atom (Ca1) is octahedrally coordinated. Blue-colored atoms denote oxygens that represent O-centers in the phosphonate headgroup of the calixarene. The disorder present in Ca2 is evident in the pairs of oxygen atoms in close proximity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Diagram displaying the bridging and coordination of calcium atoms in complex 1, where two calcium atoms (Ca2 and Ca3) are seven-coordinated and one calcium atom (Ca1) is octahedrally coordinated. Blue-colored atoms denote oxygens that represent O-centers in the phosphonate headgroup of the calixarene. The disorder present in Ca2 is evident in the pairs of oxygen atoms in close proximity.

cln_elements.content: Packing diagrams of complex (a) 1 and (b) 2. Complex 1 is viewed down the c axis, and complex 2 is viewed down the b axis. The calixarene molecules are represented by spacefilling diagrams, whereas the calcium atoms and coordinated waters have been left as ball and stick representation, with hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity. Noteworthy are the extra waters coordinated to the calciums of 1 and the closer packing of the calixarenes in 2.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Packing diagrams of complex (a) 1 and (b) 2. Complex 1 is viewed down the c axis, and complex 2 is viewed down the b axis. The calixarene molecules are represented by spacefilling diagrams, whereas the calcium atoms and coordinated waters have been left as ball and stick representation, with hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity. Noteworthy are the extra waters coordinated to the calciums of 1 and the closer packing of the calixarenes in 2.

cln_elements.content: Hirshfeld surface fingerprint plots for the calixarene moieties in complex 1 (left) and complex 2 (right) showing the distinct differences in the coordination of both calixarenes. In calculating these plots, we modeled disordered water (structure 1) and phosphonate groups (structure 2) as fully occupied over one position, instead of disordered over two positions. Structures 3 and 4 represent the parent p-phosphonic acid calix[4]arene, whose crystal structures incorporating methanol and water, respectively, in the calixarene cavity have been published in a previous paper.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Hirshfeld surface fingerprint plots for the calixarene moieties in complex 1 (left) and complex 2 (right) showing the distinct differences in the coordination of both calixarenes. In calculating these plots, we modeled disordered water (structure 1) and phosphonate groups (structure 2) as fully occupied over one position, instead of disordered over two positions. Structures 3 and 4 represent the parent p-phosphonic acid calix[4]arene, whose crystal structures incorporating methanol and water, respectively, in the calixarene cavity have been published in a previous paper.

cln_elements.content: d norm surface representation of complex (a) 1 and (b) 2, mapped over the same color range. Less protonated 1 displays an O···H or O···Ca bond length shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of the two atoms, and this is displayed as red on the surface. Complex 2, with a net positive charge lower than that of 1, is characterized by fewer red spots on the d norm surface, thus indicating that the contacts in this molecule are closer to the sum of the van der Waals radii of the atoms.

metadata.title:
Variable Intercalation of Calcium Ions in Bilayers of Partially Deprotonated p-Phosphonic Acid Calix[4]arene
Ca+ Ions in p-Phosphonic Acid Calix[4]arene
